docs.lead_paragraph: Before the voting comes the speechmaking.

headline.main: A Day for Speechifying as Finance Panel Takes Up Bill

docs.abstract: As the Senate Finance Committee takes up the big health care bill on Tuesday, the first order of business will be opening statements -- probably from all 23 committee members.
docs.snippet: As the Senate Finance Committee takes up the big health care bill on Tuesday, the first order of business will be opening statements -- probably from all 23 committee members.

docs.lead_paragraph: Bill Scher, left, of the Campaign for America's Future and Matt Lewis of Politics Daily debate Senator Max Baucus's health care bill.

headline.sub: But Will His Bill Pass Anyway?

docs.snippet: Bill Scher, left, of the Campaign for America's Future and Matt Lewis of Politics Daily debate Senator Max Baucus's health care bill.

docs.lead_paragraph: When the Senate Finance Committee takes up its health-care bill on Tuesday, activists who favor a public option plan to stage demonstrations nationwide against the health insurance industry.

headline.main: Supporters of Public Option Plan Nationwide Protest

docs.abstract: Activists who favor a 'public option' are planning to stage demonstrations nationwide Tuesday against the health insurance industry.
docs.snippet: Activists who favor a 'public option' are planning to stage demonstrations nationwide Tuesday against the health insurance industry.

docs.lead_paragraph: Saying he has heard his critics, the chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, Max Baucus, said Monday in an interview that he would modify his health care bill to provide more generous assistance to moderate-income Americans, to help them buy insurance. He also said he would make changes to reduce the impact of a proposed tax on high-end health insurance policies. Mr. Baucus, a Montana Democrat, disclosed his plans in an interview a day before the committee is to begin meeting to debate and vote on sweeping legislation to remake the health care system and guarantee insurance for millions of Americans. Read the full article.

headline.main: Baucus Says He'll Revise Plan, to Make Insurance More Affordable

docs.abstract: Senator Baucus plans to revise his plan to make insurance more affordable to moderate-income Americans and to reduce the impact of a new tax on the most expensive insurance policies.
docs.snippet: Senator Baucus plans to revise his plan to make insurance more affordable to moderate-income Americans and to reduce the impact of a new tax on the most expensive insurance policies.

docs.lead_paragraph: A central question in the debate over how to revamp the American health care system is whether insurance will be affordable for people who currently do not have it.

headline.main: What's an Affordable Premium for You?

docs.abstract: The Baucus proposal contains formulae for determining what families should pay for insurance. Could your family afford it?
docs.snippet: The Baucus proposal contains formulae for determining what families should pay for insurance. Could your family afford it?

docs.lead_paragraph: Aroldis Chapman, the talented Cuban pitcher who defected while at a tournament in the Netherlands two months ago, has moved closer to becoming a major league free agent. Chapman has been granted provisional passive residency in the country of Andorra, according to Athletes Premier International, his agents.

headline.main: Cuban Defector Moves Closer to Free Agency

docs.abstract: Aroldis Chapman, the talented Cuban pitcher who defected while at a tournament in the Netherlands two months ago, has been granted provisional passive residency in Andorra, according to Athletes Premier International, his agents.
docs.snippet: Aroldis Chapman, the talented Cuban pitcher who defected while at a tournament in the Netherlands two months ago, has been granted provisional passive residency in Andorra, according to Athletes Premier International, his agents.

docs.lead_paragraph: A signature component of the health care legislation in the Senate Finance Committee is a proposal to tax expensive health insurance plans above a certain cutoff. Not only is this provision meant to help raise $215 billion toward the cost of the bill, but the Congressional Budget Office calculates that it would help slow the steep rise in health care inflation.

headline.main: Name a State, Four Letters, Starts With 'U'

docs.abstract: A vowel for $215 billion, please. Orrin Hatch doesn't like a measure in health care legislation that benefits people in states with high insurance costs. He wants to include any state that begins with the letter "U."
docs.snippet: A vowel for $215 billion, please. Orrin Hatch doesn't like a measure in health care legislation that benefits people in states with high insurance costs. He wants to include any state that begins with the letter "U."

docs.lead_paragraph: Nancy Folbre is an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts Amherst.

headline.main: Valuing Unpaid Work Matters, Especially for the Poor

docs.abstract: An economist argues for paying more attention to unpaid work, since working for pay actually costs money - the money required to purchase substitutes for family care.
docs.snippet: An economist argues for paying more attention to unpaid work, since working for pay actually costs money - the money required to purchase substitutes for family care.

docs.lead_paragraph: The senior Senate Democrat shepherding legislation to overhaul the nation's financial system is planning to propose the merger of four bank agencies into one super-regulator, an idea that is significantly different from what President Obama envisions, The New York Times's Stephen Labaton reported.

headline.main: Dodd Pushing a New Plan to Oversee Banks

docs.abstract: Senator Christopher J. Dodd is planning to propose the merger of four bank agencies into one super-regulator, an idea that is significantly different from what President Obama envisions.
docs.snippet: Senator Christopher J. Dodd is planning to propose the merger of four bank agencies into one super-regulator, an idea that is significantly different from what President Obama envisions.
